ground_truth: Holmes looks into the corridor, steps into a compartment, and shoos the elderly couple out of their compartment. A soldier opens a crate, takes out a Maxim machine gun, fixes it onto its tripod, and loads the belt-fed ammunition into the breech. The weapon is cocked, and the soldier opens fire, with bullets ripping through the walls of the first class compartments, showering Watson and Holmes with debris. Watson closes the exterior door and sees Holmes lying down. Holmes pulls Watson down beside him, lights a pipe, and hands Watson a pistol. The lipstick Holmes put in the machine gun belt jams the gun. Watson shoots through the hole created by the machine gun bullets, hitting a soldier who drops a grenade. The soldier realizes he's inadvertently pulled the pin out of the grenade, which then drops back into a bag full of grenades. The grenades explode, blasting the train in two. The train rattles on through the night as Watson and Holmes sit in the ruined lavatory of their carriage, which is at the end of those still attached to the engine. A flashback to her falling from the train is followed by Mycroft appearing in a boat. Holmes, whose face is smeared with lipstick and eye shadow, waits awkwardly for the answer while Watson smiles ruefully at the mention of Paris. Black smoke belches from the funnels of a paddle-steamer as it leaves the white cliffs of Dover behind, with Watson and Holmes, now out of disguise, on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson takes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief out of Sims' bag, glances at Holmes, who takes the hanky, walks to the railing, sniffs it, and then looks out to sea. Watson watches Holmes closely as Holmes looks down at the hanky, glances over his shoulder at Watson, and casually tosses it over the side. The paddle-steamer approaches the French coast. A flier posted on a wall in Paris advertises a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Inside a grand building, Moriarty is signing a copy of his book on asteroids for an admirer, hands it back, and as another man approaches, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty looks at the note, puts it in a leather covered notebook, signs another book, turns to his agent, and the agent takes two tickets from his jacket pocket before leaving. Outside, the agent wanders over to a rough looking bloke leaning against a wall.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Holmes peers into the hallway, strides into a compartment, and ushers the elderly duo out of their compartment. A soldier unseals a crate, extracts a Maxim machine gun, affixes it onto its tripod, and fills the belt-fed munitions into the breech. The weapon is cocked, and the soldier unleashes fire, with bullets tearing through the barriers of the first class compartments, pelting Watson and Holmes with fragments. Watson shuts the outer door and notices Holmes reclining. Holmes tugs Watson down beside him, ignites a pipe, and hands Watson a revolver. The lipstick Holmes inserted in the machine gun belt obstructs the gun. Watson fires through the cavity created by the machine gun bullets, striking a soldier who drops a grenade. The soldier understands he's inadvertently pulled the pin out of the grenade, which then falls back into a sack full of grenades. The grenades detonate, blasting the train in two. The train clatters on through the dark as Watson and Holmes sit in the shattered lavatory of their carriage, which is at the end of those still linked to the engine. A flashback to her descending from the train is followed by Mycroft appearing in a vessel. Holmes, whose visage is smeared with lipstick and eye shadow, waits awkwardly for the response while Watson smiles ruefully at the mention of Paris. Black smoke erupts from the funnels of a paddle-steamer as it departs the white cliffs of Dover behind, with Watson and Holmes, now out of disguise, on the steamer's aft promenade deck. Watson removes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief out of Sims' bag, glances at Holmes, who takes the hanky, strolls to the railing, sniffs it, and then gazes out to sea. Watson observes Holmes intently as Holmes looks down at the hanky, glances over his shoulder at Watson, and nonchalantly tosses it over the edge. The paddle-steamer nears the French shore. A flier posted on a wall in Paris promotes a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Inside a grand structure, Moriarty is signing a copy of his book on asteroids for an admirer, hands it back, and as another man approaches, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty examines the note, places it in a leather bound notebook, signs another book, turns to his agent, and the agent removes two tickets from his jacket pocket before departing. Outside, the agent ambles over to a rough looking chap leaning against a wall.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Holmes looks into the corridor, steps into a compartment, and the elderly couple is shooed out of their compartment by him. A crate is opened by a soldier, who takes out a Maxim machine gun, fixes it onto its tripod, and loads the belt-fed ammunition into the breech. He cocks the weapon and opens fire, with bullets ripping through the walls of the first class compartments, showering Watson and Holmes with debris. The exterior door is closed by Watson and Holmes is seen lying down by him. Watson is pulled down beside him by Holmes, who lights a pipe and hands him a pistol. The lipstick that Holmes put in the machine gun belt jams the gun. Through the hole created by the machine gun bullets, Watson shoots, hitting a soldier who drops a grenade. The soldier realizes he's inadvertently pulled the pin out of the grenade and it then drops back into a bag full of grenades. The grenades explode, blasting the train in two. The train is rattled on through the night as Watson and Holmes sit in the ruined lavatory of their carriage, which is at the end of those still attached to the engine. Her falling from the train is flashed back to before Mycroft appears in a boat. Holmes, whose face is smeared with lipstick and eye shadow, waits awkwardly for the answer while at the mention of Paris, Watson smiles ruefully. Black smoke is belched from the funnels of a paddle-steamer as the white cliffs of Dover are left behind by it, with Watson and Holmes, now out of disguise, on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Out of Sims' bag, Watson takes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief, glances at Holmes, who takes the hanky, walks to the railing, sniffs it, and then looks out to sea. Holmes is watched closely by Watson as he looks down at the hanky, glances over his shoulder at Watson, and casually tosses it over the side. The French coast is approached by the paddle-steamer. A flier posted on a wall in Paris advertises a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Inside a grand building, a copy of his book on asteroids is signed by Moriarty for an admirer, handed back, and as another man approaches, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty looks at the note, puts it in a leather-covered notebook, signs another book, turns to his agent, and two tickets are taken from his jacket pocket by the agent before leaving. Outside, over to a rough-looking bloke leaning against a wall, the agent wanders.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Holmes enters a compartment, politely removing an elderly couple. A soldier readies a Maxim machine gun, sets it on a tripod, loads it, and fires, causing debris to shower Watson and Holmes. Watson shuts the door, sees Holmes lying down, joins him, and receives a pipe and pistol. A lipstick Holmes placed jams the gun. Watson fires through a bullet hole, hitting a soldier who drops a grenade, unknowingly pulling the pin, causing an explosion that splits the train. Watson and Holmes remain in their wrecked carriage at the end of the train. A flashback shows a fall from the train, then Mycroft appears in a boat. Holmes, wearing smudged makeup, waits for a response as Watson smiles at the mention of Paris. Smoke rises from a paddle-steamer leaving Dover as Holmes and Watson, no longer in disguise, stand on deck. Watson retrieves Irene's handkerchief from Sims' bag; Holmes sniffs it, then tosses it overboard. Approaching France, a flier in Paris announces a Professor Moriarty lecture. Inside a grand building, Moriarty signs a book on asteroids, receives a note from a bearded agent, who then takes tickets from his jacket before leaving. The agent approaches a rough-looking man outside.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Holmes enters a compartment, ejecting an elderly couple. A soldier sets up a Maxim machine gun, loads it, and fires, sending bullets and debris onto Watson and Holmes. Watson closes the door and sees Holmes lying down. Holmes pulls Watson down, lights a pipe, and gives him a pistol. Lipstick jams the gun, and Watson shoots a soldier, who drops a grenade into a bag of grenades, causing an explosion that splits the train. As the train continues, Watson and Holmes are in a damaged carriage. After a flashback, Mycroft appears in a boat. Holmes, with lipstick and eye shadow, waits for an answer while Watson smiles at the mention of Paris. A paddle-steamer leaves Dover as Watson and Holmes, out of disguise, stand on the deck. Watson takes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief, hands it to Holmes, who sniffs it and tosses it overboard. The steamer nears France. In Paris, a flier announces a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Moriarty, inside a grand building, signs a book on asteroids, receives a note from his agent, and pockets it. The agent leaves with two tickets and approaches a rough-looking man outside.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Holmes, with a keen and observant gaze, peers into the dimly lit corridor before making his way into a nearby compartment. With a sense of urgency and authority, he politely yet firmly urges the elderly couple occupying the space to vacate their compartment. Meanwhile, a soldier, showing precision and determination, proceeds to open a large crate. From within the confines of the crate, the soldier retrieves a Maxim machine gun, which he meticulously attaches to its sturdy tripod. With practiced hands, he loads the belt-fed ammunition into the gun's breech. The weapon is then cocked, and, without hesitation, the soldier opens fire with a relentless stream of bullets. These projectiles tear through the walls of the first-class compartments, sending a shower of debris cascading onto Watson and Holmes. Reacting swiftly, Watson secures the exterior door shut, glancing over to find Holmes already prone on the floor. Holmes beckons Watson to join him, pulling him down to safety alongside him, then casually lights a pipe and hands Watson a pistol, signaling readiness. An unorthodox tactic comes into effect as the lipstick that Holmes had cleverly slipped into the machine gun's belt causes the weapon to jam. Seizing the opportunity, Watson carefully aims and fires through the hole created by the earlier gunfire, successfully hitting a soldier. The soldier, in shock, inadvertently drops a grenade. In a moment of panic, he realizes that the pin has been removed and the grenade plummets back into a bag filled with other grenades. A catastrophic explosion follows, violently splitting the train in two. As the night deepens, the train continues its journey, rattling along the tracks. Watson and Holmes find themselves seated in the destroyed lavatory of their carriage, which is precariously positioned at the end of the train segments still connected to the engine. The narrative then offers a flashback to her dramatic fall from the train, followed by the unexpected appearance of Mycroft aboard a boat. Holmes, his face humorously smeared with lipstick and eye shadow, waits in an awkward silence for a response while Watson, with a rueful smile, acknowledges the mention of Paris. The scene shifts to black smoke belching ominously from the funnels of a paddle-steamer, which is steadily leaving the iconic white cliffs of Dover behind. Watson and Holmes, having shed their disguises, are now standing on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson retrieves a monogrammed handkerchief belonging to Irene from Sims' bag, casting a glance at Holmes. Holmes, accepting the hanky, walks to the railing, inhales its scent thoughtfully, and gazes out towards the vast sea. Watson observes Holmes intently as Holmes glances down at the hanky, then back at Watson, before nonchalantly tossing the handkerchief overboard. As the paddle-steamer gradually approaches the distant French coast, a flier prominently displayed on a wall in Paris captures attention, advertising an upcoming lecture by the notorious Professor Moriarty. Within a grand, imposing building, Moriarty is engaged in signing a copy of his latest book on asteroids for an admirer. Handing it back with a polite nod, he turns his attention to another approaching individual. Nearby, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and discreetly passes him a note. Moriarty examines the note, then calmly tucks it into a leather-covered notebook. Continuing his task with unwavering focus, he signs another book and turns to his agent. The agent, in turn, retrieves two tickets from his jacket pocket before departing the scene. Outside, the agent casually makes his way over to a rough-looking individual who is leaning nonchalantly against a wall, deep in thought.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: With a keen and observant gaze that missed nothing, Holmes peers into the dimly lit corridor, taking in every detail, before deciding to proceed into a nearby compartment. With a sense of urgency emanating from his very being and exuding an air of authority, he politely yet firmly urges the elderly couple who are occupying the space to vacate their compartment immediately. Meanwhile, elsewhere on the scene, a soldier, displaying precision and determination, goes about the task of opening a large crate. From within the confines of this sturdy crate, the soldier retrieves a formidable Maxim machine gun, which he then meticulously attaches to its sturdy tripod, ensuring everything is in place. With practiced hands that speak of experience, he carefully loads the belt-fed ammunition into the machine gun's breech. The weapon is then cocked, and, without a moment's hesitation, the soldier unleashes a relentless stream of bullets. These projectiles tear mercilessly through the walls of the first-class compartments, sending a cascading shower of debris crashing down onto Watson and Holmes. Reacting with the swiftness of instinct, Watson secures the exterior door shut, casting a glance over to discover Holmes already lying prone on the floor. Holmes beckons Watson to join him, pulling him down to safety beside him, then casually lights a pipe and hands Watson a pistol, signaling readiness for the next unpredictable turn of events. An unorthodox tactic brilliantly comes into play as the lipstick that Holmes had cleverly slipped into the machine gun's belt causes the weapon to jam. Seizing this unexpected opportunity, Watson carefully takes aim and fires through the hole created by the earlier gunfire, successfully hitting a soldier. The soldier, taken aback and in shock, inadvertently drops a grenade. In a moment of panic, realizing with horror that the pin has been removed, the grenade plummets back into a bag filled with other grenades. A catastrophic explosion follows, violently splitting the train in two, sending shockwaves through the night. As the night deepens and takes on a more mysterious hue, the train continues its journey, rattling along the tracks with a relentless rhythm. Watson and Holmes find themselves seated precariously in the destroyed lavatory of their carriage, which is now positioned perilously at the end of the train segments still connected to the engine. The narrative then offers a flashback, taking us back to the dramatic fall from the train, followed by the unexpected and surprising appearance of Mycroft aboard a boat. Holmes, his face humorously smeared with lipstick and eye shadow, waits in an awkward silence for some kind of response, while Watson, with a rueful smile, acknowledges the mention of Paris. The scene shifts dramatically to black smoke belching ominously from the funnels of a paddle-steamer, which is steadily leaving the iconic white cliffs of Dover behind. Watson and Holmes, having shed their disguises, now stand on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson retrieves a monogrammed handkerchief belonging to Irene from Sims' bag, casting a meaningful glance at Holmes. Holmes, accepting the handkerchief with a moment of contemplation, walks over to the railing, inhales its scent thoughtfully, and then gazes out towards the vast, endless sea. Watson observes Holmes intently as Holmes glances down at the handkerchief, then back at Watson, before nonchalantly tossing the handkerchief overboard, letting it vanish into the water. As the paddle-steamer gradually approaches the distant French coast, a flier prominently displayed on a wall in Paris captures the attention of passersby, advertising an upcoming lecture by the notorious Professor Moriarty. Within a grand, imposing building, Moriarty is engaged in the act of signing a copy of his latest book, focused on the subject of asteroids, for an admirer who eagerly anticipates the exchange. Handing it back with a polite nod, he turns his attention to another approaching individual. Nearby, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and discreetly passes him a note with an air of secrecy. Moriarty examines the note in detail, then calmly tucks it away into a leather-covered notebook for safekeeping. Continuing his task with unwavering focus, he signs another book and then turns to his agent. The agent, in turn, retrieves two tickets from his jacket pocket before departing the scene with casual confidence. Outside, the agent casually makes his way over to a rough-looking individual who is leaning nonchalantly against a nearby wall, seemingly deep in thought.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Holmes carefully peers into the dimly lit corridor, assessing his surroundings before confidently stepping into an adjacent compartment. Inside, he finds an elderly couple, whom he politely yet firmly ushers out, claiming their space for his own purposes. Meanwhile, a soldier methodically opens a sturdy crate to reveal a Maxim machine gun nested inside. With practiced efficiency, he retrieves the weapon and sets it down, ensuring it's securely mounted on its tripod. He methodically feeds the belt-fed ammunition into the breech, preparing the gun for action. The soldier then cocks the weapon, setting the complex mechanics into motion, and with a finger poised on the trigger, he opens fire. The deafening roar of the gun is immediately followed by a hail of bullets, which perforate the walls of the first-class compartments, sending splinters and debris raining down on Watson and Holmes. Reacting swiftly to the assault, Watson rushes to close the exterior door, only to turn around and find Holmes lying prone on the floor, seemingly at ease. Holmes beckons Watson to join him on the floor and, with a calculated calmness, lights a pipe, drawing in the smoke before exhaling slowly. He then hands Watson a pistol, preparing him for the impending confrontation. As the chaos continues, the lipstick Holmes had cleverly inserted into the machine gun belt causes a malfunction, jamming the gun at a critical moment. Seizing the opportunity, Watson takes aim through a newly created hole in the wall, courtesy of the machine gun's bullets, and fires, striking a soldier. In a moment of sheer panic, the wounded soldier inadvertently drops a grenade, having unknowingly pulled the pin. As the grenade falls back into a bag brimming with explosives, a catastrophic explosion erupts, shearing the train in two. The train lurches violently as it continues to rumble through the night, now a mere shell of its former self. Inside the battered remains of a lavatory at the end of the carriage still tethered to the engine, Watson and Holmes sit in reflective silence. A flashback interrupts the moment, vividly recalling the image of Irene falling from the train, which seamlessly transitions into the jarring appearance of Mycroft in a boat. Back in the present, Holmes awkwardly waits for an answer, his face comically smeared with lipstick and eyeshadow, while Watson can't help but smile ruefully at the mention of Paris. As the scene shifts, thick, black smoke billows from the funnels of a paddle-steamer, leaving the iconic white cliffs of Dover in its wake. Watson and Holmes, now devoid of their disguises, are positioned on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson, in a contemplative mood, retrieves Irene's monogrammed handkerchief from Sims' bag, casting a sideways glance at Holmes. Holmes takes the delicate hanky, walks leisurely to the railing, and inhales its lingering scent before gazing out at the endless sea. With Watson observing him closely, Holmes briefly studies the hanky, then, with a nonchalant flick of his wrist, lets it drift over the side into the churning waters below. As the paddle-steamer steadily approaches the French coast, the bustling cityscape of Paris fills the frame. A boldly printed flier affixed to a wall announces an upcoming lecture by the esteemed Professor Moriarty. Inside an opulent building, Moriarty is seated at a lavish table, graciously signing his book on asteroids for a waiting admirer. He returns the signed copy and acknowledges another approaching man with a nod. Seated nearby, a bearded agent quietly joins Moriarty and discreetly passes him a note. Moriarty's eyes scan the note before he carefully tucks it into a leather-bound notebook. With practiced elegance, he signs yet another book before turning to his agent, who promptly fishes out two tickets from his jacket pocket. The agent rises to leave, stepping outside to merge with the bustling streets of Paris. He meanders toward a rough-looking bloke, who is casually leaning against a sun-drenched wall, setting the stage for yet another chapter in the unfolding saga.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Holmes enters a train compartment and promptly evicts an elderly couple. Meanwhile, a soldier sets up a Maxim machine gun, fires it through first-class compartments, and sends debris flying around Watson and Holmes. Watson secures the compartment door and notices Holmes lighting a pipe and handing him a pistol. The machine gun jams due to lipstick placed in the ammunition, allowing Watson to shoot and hit a soldier, who drops a grenade into a bag of explosives, causing a massive detonation that splits the train. The train continues into the night, with Holmes and Watson seated in the wrecked lavatory of their carriage, which remains attached to the engine. A flashback shows a fall from the train, transitioning to Mycroft's arrival by boat. Holmes, with a face streaked with makeup, awkwardly anticipates a response as Watson smiles at the mention of Paris. As a paddle-steamer departs from Dover, Holmes and Watson, no longer in disguise, are on the rear promenade deck. Watson retrieves Irene's monogrammed handkerchief from Sims' bag, gives it to Holmes, who smells it, and then tosses it overboard as he scans the sea. As the steamer nears the French coast, a flier in Paris advertises a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Inside a grand building, Moriarty signs books on asteroids for admirers. During this, a bearded agent discreetly hands Moriarty a note, which he places in a leather notebook before continuing to sign books. The agent then extracts two tickets from his pocket and leaves to confer with a rugged-looking man outside.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Holmes, the renowned detective known for his keen observation and deduction skills, looks into the corridor, steps into a train compartment, and shoos the elderly couple out of their compartment with an urgent yet polite demeanor. A soldier, part of a security detail common in times of heightened tension, opens a military-grade crate, takes out a Maxim machine gun, a groundbreaking weapon first used in the late 19th century for its rapid-fire capability, fixes it onto its tripod, and loads the belt-fed ammunition into the breech. The weapon is cocked, and the soldier opens fire, bullets ripping through the walls of the first class compartments of the luxury train, showering Watson and Holmes with debris. Watson, ensuring their safety, closes the exterior door and sees Holmes lying down in a strategic position. Holmes pulls Watson down beside him, lights a pipe with a calmness that belies the situation, and hands Watson a pistol. The lipstick Holmes put in the machine gun belt, a clever sabotage, jams the gun. Watson shoots through the hole created by the machine gun bullets, skillfully hitting a soldier who, in a panic, drops a grenade. The soldier realizes he's inadvertently pulled the pin out of the grenade, which then drops back into a bag full of explosives designed for demolition. The grenades explode, blasting the train in two with a force that echoes through the night. The train rattles on through the night as Watson and Holmes sit in the ruined lavatory of their carriage, which is at the end of those still attached to the engine, a testament to the train's sturdy construction. A flashback to her, perhaps a key character in Holmes’s investigations, falling from the train is followed by Mycroft, Holmes’s brother who works for the British government, appearing in a boat. Holmes, whose face is smeared with lipstick and eye shadow from his earlier disguise, waits awkwardly for the answer while Watson smiles ruefully at the mention of Paris, a city deeply connected with their current case. Black smoke belches from the funnels of a paddle-steamer, a type of steamship historically used for cross-channel travel, as it leaves the iconic white cliffs of Dover behind, with Watson and Holmes, now out of disguise, on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson takes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief out of Sims' bag, a personal item carrying the scent of the mysterious Irene Adler, glances at Holmes, who takes the hanky, walks to the railing, sniffs it, and then looks out to the English Channel's sea. Watson watches Holmes closely as Holmes looks down at the hanky, glances over his shoulder at Watson, and casually tosses it over the side, a gesture perhaps signifying his readiness to move forward. The paddle-steamer approaches the French coast, a land synonymous with artistic brilliance and intellectual discourse. A flier posted on a wall in Paris, a city known for its vibrant cultural scene, advertises a lecture by Professor Moriarty, Holmes's arch-nemesis and a criminal mastermind. Inside a grand building with opulent architecture, Moriarty is signing a copy of his book on asteroids, a subject of both scientific fascination and practicality, for an admirer, hands it back, and as another man approaches, a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty looks at the note, puts it in a leather covered notebook, symbolic of his meticulous nature, signs another book, turns to his agent, and the agent takes two tickets from his jacket pocket before leaving, possibly setting the stage for their next move. Outside, the agent wanders over to a rough looking bloke, who could be an informant or an accomplice, leaning against a wall, setting the scene for further intrigue.

Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Holmes whose face is smeared with lipstick and eye shadow waits awkwardly for the answer while Watson smiles ruefully at the mention of Paris. Black smoke belches from the funnels of a paddlesteamer as it leaves the white cliffs of Dover behind with Watson and Holmes now out of disguise on the steamer's rear promenade deck. Watson takes Irene's monogrammed handkerchief out of Sims' bag glances at Holmes who takes the hanky walks to the railing sniffs it and then looks out to sea. Watson watches Holmes closely as Holmes looks down at the hanky glances over his shoulder at Watson and casually tosses it over the side. The paddlesteamer approaches the French coast. A flier posted on a wall in Paris advertises a lecture by Professor Moriarty. Inside a grand building Moriarty is signing a copy of his book on asteroids for an admirer hands it back and as another man approaches a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty looks at the note puts it in. a leather covered notebook signs. another book turns to his agent and the agent takes two tickets from his jacket pocket before leaving. Outside. the agent wanders over to a rough looking bloke leaning against a wall.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Holmes looks into the corridor steps into a compartment and shoos the elderly couple out of their compartment. A soldier opens a crate takes out a Maxim machine gun fixes it onto its tripod and loads the beltfed ammunition into the breech. The weapon is cocked and the soldier opens fire with bullets ripping through the walls of the first class compartments showering Watson and Holmes with debris. Watson closes the exterior door and sees Holmes lying down. Holmes pulls Watson down beside him lights a pipe and hands Watson a pistol. The lipstick Holmes put in the machine gun belt jams the gun. Inside a grand building Moriarty is signing a copy of his book on asteroids for an admirer hands it back and as another man approaches a bearded agent sits beside Moriarty and passes him a note. Moriarty looks at the note puts it in. a leather covered notebook signs. another book turns to his agent and the agent takes two tickets from his jacket pocket before leaving. Outside. the agent wanders over to a rough looking bloke leaning against a wall.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Holmes looks into the corridor steps into a compartment and shoos the elderly couple out of their compartment. A soldier opens a crate takes out a Maxim machine gun fixes it onto its tripod and loads the beltfed ammunition into the breech. another book turns to his agent and the agent takes two tickets from his jacket pocket before leaving. Outside. the agent wanders over to a rough looking bloke leaning against a wall.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Griffin peers into the banquet hall, leaps into a hammock, and nudges the young gardener out of their hammock. A pilot lifts a suitcase, pulls out a saxophone, mounts it on its stand, and slots the harmonica into the case. The instrument is strummed, and the pilot starts singing, with rhythms echoing through the alleys of the upper decks, showering Potter and Griffin with feathers. Potter locks the cellar door and notices Griffin reclining. Griffin drags Potter beside him, lights a candle, and hands Potter a flute. The bookmark Griffin inserted in the harmonica case halts the singing. Potter whispers through the gap created by the saxophone rhythms, alerting a pilot who drops a maraca. The pilot realizes he's inadvertently flipped the lid off the maraca, which then tumbles back into a box full of maracas. The maracas clatter, splitting the airplane in two. The airplane glides on through the afternoon as Potter and Griffin curl in the dusty alcove of their cabin, which is at the front of those still connected to the fuselage. A flashback to him climbing onto the airplane is followed by Edgar appearing in a raft. Griffin, whose face is painted with chalk and glitter, waits patiently for the story while Potter laughs softly at the mention of Vienna. Purple ribbons fly from the towers of a power-plant as it leaves the sandy beaches of Brighton behind, with Potter and Griffin, now in costume, on the power-plant's top observation deck. Potter pulls Ben's engraved pocket watch out of Cass' box, nods at Griffin, who grabs the watch, strolls to the fence, flicks it, and then gazes out to river. Potter observes Griffin keenly as Griffin peers at the watch, glances over his shoulder at Potter, and casually flips it into the air. The power-plant approaches the Spanish shoreline. A banner hanging on a kiosk in Lisbon announces a festival featuring Dr. Doolittle. Within a modest library, Doolittle is sketching an image of his journal on maps for a guest, returns it, and as a woman steps up, a masked courier stands opposite Doolittle and hands him a package. Doolittle inspects the package, fits it in a cardboard envelope, sketches another map, faces his courier, and the courier pulls two apples from his briefcase before departing. Nearby, the courier drifts over to a weary merchant lounging against a balcony.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Holmes enters a train compartment, ejecting an elderly couple. A soldier sets up a Maxim machine gun, firing and sending debris at Holmes and Watson. Holmes, preparing for action, hands Watson a pistol. A lipstick jams the gun, allowing Watson to shoot a soldier who accidentally detonates grenades, splitting the train. Seated in a ruined carriage, Holmes and Watson recall events, including Mycroft's appearance in a boat. Now on a paddle-steamer, they leave Dover, discarding Irene's monogrammed handkerchief into the sea as they approach France. In Paris, Professor Moriarty, the antagonist, signs books and receives a note from an agent. The agent discreetly passes two tickets to someone outside.
